Definition.WordDefinition: Funk, NE (village, FIPS 17880) Location: 40.46294 N, 99.24953 W Population (1990): 198 (82 housing units) Area: 0.7 sq km (land), 0.0 sq km (water) Zip code(s): 68940

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Funk \Funk\ (f[u^][ng]k), n. [OE. funke a little fire; akin to Prov. E. funk touchwood, G. funke spark, and perh. to Goth. f[=o]n fire.] 1. An offensive smell; a stench. [Low] [1913 Webster]
2. One who funks; a shirk; a coward. [Colloq.] [Webster 1913 Suppl.]
3. a state of fear. [PJC]
4. a mildly depressed state of mind; -- often used in the phrase {blue funk}. [PJC]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Funk \Funk\ (f[u^][ng]k), n. an earthy, seemingly unsophisticated style of jazz music having elements of black American blues and gospel. [PJC]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Funk \Funk\, v. t. 1. To envelop with an offensive smell or smoke. [Obs.] --King. [1913 Webster]
2. To funk at; to flinch at; to shrink from (a thing or person); as, to funk a task. [Colloq.] [Webster 1913 Suppl.]
3. To frighten; to cause to flinch. [Colloq.] [Webster 1913 Suppl.]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Funk \Funk\, v. i. 1. To emit an offensive smell; to stink. [1913 Webster]
2. To be frightened, and shrink back; to flinch; as, to funk at the edge of a precipice. [Colloq.] --C. Kingsley. [1913 Webster]
{To funk out}, to back out in a cowardly fashion. [Colloq.] [1913 Webster]
To funk right out o' political strife. --Lowell (Biglow Papers).

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Funk \Funk\, Funking \Funk"ing\, n. A shrinking back through fear. [Colloq.] ``The horrid panic, or funk (as the men of Eton call it).'' --De Quincey. [1913 Webster]

funk n 1: a state of nervous depression; "he was in a funk" [syn: {blue funk}] 2: United States biochemist (born in Poland) who showed that several diseases were caused by dietary deficiencies and who coined the term `vitamin' for the chemicals involved (1884-1967) [syn: {Casimir Funk}] v : draw back, as with fear or pain; "she flinched when they showed the slaughtering of the calf" [syn: {flinch}, {squinch}, {cringe}, {shrink}, {wince}, {recoil}, {quail}]
